channel.title: IETF-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by IETF

item.title: [rfc7231] Issue with "Expect": meet vs fulfill the expectations - use "meet the expectations" consistency issue and make a description simpler
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Expect

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

use "meet the expectations" consistency issue and make a description simpler

Specific section or headline?

The Expect HTTP request header indicates expectations that need to be fulfilled by the server in order to properly handle the request.

The only expectation defined in the specification is Expect: 100-continue, to which the server shall respond with:
100 if the information contained in the header is sufficient to cause an immediate success,
417 (Expectation Failed) if it cannot meet the expectation; or any other 4xx status otherwise.

What did you expect to see?

The Expect HTTP request header indicates the expectations that need to be met by the server. As a result, the request is successfully processed.

Upon the "Expect: 100-continue" expectations, the server responds with:
100 (Expectation Succeeded) - if the information from the header is sufficient to cause immediate success
417 (Expectation Failed) or any other 4xx status - if the server cannot meet the expectation.

Did you test this? If so, how?

yes, the specialist should read it and approve if the meaning is not changed, and if no knowledge is lost

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/http/headers/expect
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Expect
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/http/headers/expect/index.md
  • Last commit: 4623499
  • Document last modified: 2021-08-13T16:17:49.000Z

item.title: [rfc7231] Issue with "Preflight request": preflight/options requests are not cacheable
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Preflight_request

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

"The preflight response can be optionally cached for the requests created in the same URL using Access-Control-Max-Age header like in the above example."

My understanding is that OPTIONS requests are NOT cacheable. You can read more about that in the spec and on the additional references that are linked on this page.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Methods/OPTIONS

It says right at the top that it is Cacheable: No

Specific section or headline?

just above the "see also" section.

What did you expect to see?

I believe that preflight / OPTIONS requests are NOT cacheable, so I wouldn't expect this page to mention caching at all.

Did you test this? If so, how?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Methods/OPTIONS
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.7

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/glossary/preflight_request
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Preflight_request
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/glossary/preflight_request/index.html
  • Last commit: 5621100
  • Document last modified: 2021-07-02T08:15:08.000Z

item.title: [rfc7234] Content bug: Explanation for `Cache-Control: no-store, max-age=0`
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Cache-Control#preventing_caching

Specific page section or heading?

Note: The no-store directive will prevent a new resource being cached, but it will not prevent the cache from responding with a non-stale resource that was cached as the result of an earlier request. Setting max-age=0 as well forces the cache to revalidate (clears the cache).
Cache-Control: no-store, max-age=0

What is the problem?

Is the line below really true ?

Setting max-age=0 as well forces the cache to revalidate (clears the cache).

IIUC, no-store doesn't stored in any cache storage according to spec.

So any directive combined with no-store doesn't affect any cache storage. I don't know why max-age=0 could clear the cache in previously stored response with no-store.

What did you expect to see?

If it's mentioned in the spec (which I couldn't find), it should be mentioned explicitly.
or if major implementation behave like it, it can also be linked as source.

otherwise, delete this Notes and leave it only

Cache-Control: no-store

Did you test this? If so, how?

I wanna ask how to test it who wrote this section.

item.title: [rfc7230] Issue with "Trailer": page says all browsers are compatible but there is no way to use this feature
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Trailer

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page says that Trailers are available for use in all major browsers. In fact, it seems it there is no way to use them from javascript.

Specific section or headline?

"Browser compatibility" is the main culprit but also, given the information in this SO answer, I'm a little lost as to why this page exists at all.

What did you expect to see?

Maybe a thumbs down icon with a deprecation warning. I may be missing something.

Did you test this? If so, how?

We implemented the server side of this, encouraged by this page. Now we come to depend on that from the client side we find we can't use it from the browser (neither fetch nor XMPHttpRequest) despite wall-to-wall green in the browswer compatibility table. I'd really like to understand the disconnect here (may of course be my own understanding) but in any case, I would encourage some kind of health warning on the page if possible for future visitors.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/http/headers/trailer
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Trailer
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/http/headers/trailer/index.html
  • Last commit: 30440f2
  • Document last modified: 2021-07-08T09:12:33.000Z

item.title: [rfc7232] Issue with "If-None-Match": (short summary here please)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/If-None-Match

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Apache reverse proxies will append "-gzip" suffix to well-formed ETag headers when gzip-encoding content, but they do not remove them from If-None-Match headers. See https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=39727

There are good reasons for this, since gzip-encoding the content will affect how range requests can be used. But server software that compares If-None-Match headers in requests with ETags may need to account for this.

Specific section or headline?

Unsure.

What did you expect to see?

It should be mentioned somewhere.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I cam across this while working on server code.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/http/headers/if-none-match
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/If-None-Match

  • Last commit: f6f11d2
